titleStmt.title: [University of Chicago Library GMS-0972, a manuscript catalogue description in electronic form]
titleStmt.funder: Institute of Museum and Library Services

publicationStmt.publisher: University of Chicago Library, Special Collections Research Center

overview.p: Gospel of Mark in Greek. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Grk. 38.
The manuscript is commonly known as the Archaic Mark because of characteristics evident in its text.
17 miniatures consist of a portrait of the Evangelist Mark, and depictions of events drawn primarily from the cycles of Christ's miracles and Passion.

headpieces.p: Headpiece composed of floral, foliate, and geometric designs in rose, blue, and gold (fol. 2r).

initials.p: Initial A (10 mm) in rose outlined in blue, red, and gold with gold pen-flourishing. Minor initials in gold (traces of red) set off from the text.

physDesc.extent: 44 leaves, of which 1 is a flyleaf.

foliation.p: 43 + 1 (foliated parchment flyleaf). Modern foliation in Arabic numerals in pencil 1-44.

collation.p: 6 quires of 8 leaves, with the exception of quire 6, which contains 4 leaves. The bifolium fol. 12 r-v and fol. 13 r-v was folded in reverse and bound in.

physDesc.dimensions: Written space 91 x 60 mm (fol. 9r). Variation in column length, 91 to 100 mm, and in column width, 55 to 60 mm.

layout.p: 1 column, 24-25 lines (fols. 3-16) and 20-22 lines (fols. 17-43). Ruling on both recto and verso with hard point. Lines previously ruled on the outer bifolium quire 3 (fols. 17, 24) stand at right angles to the lines of the later ruling pattern.

handDesc.p: Written in minuscule script in medium brown ink. Minor initials duplicate letters in the text or replace letters erased.

condition.p: Text abraded (fol. 18r). Some miniatures have paint losses. Quire 2 (fols. 9-16) detached from binding.

binding.p: Bound in blind stamped goatskin (reused), over thin wooden boards. Doublures of dark brown leather.

origin.p: The manuscript is dated to the late 19th or early 20th century based on the results of codicological and text critical assessments, and the scientific testing of its pigment, ink, and parchment support. Place of origin possibly Greece.

provenance.p: Belonged to John Askitopoulos (died ca. 1918), an Athenian collector and dealer in antiquities. University of Chicago Libraries bookplate (front doublure).

acquisition.p: Acquired by the University of Chicago from the family of John Askitopoulos, August 1938.

projectDesc.p: The Edgar J. Goodspeed Manuscript Collection contains 68 Greek, Armenian, Latin, Syriac, Ethiopic, and Arabic manuscripts, which range in date from the fifth to the nineteenth century. With support from the Institute of Museum and Library Services National Leadership Grants for Libraries, Building Digital Resources program, the University of Chicago Library has created the online Goodspeed Manuscript Collection, a unique digital resource with manuscripts digitized in their entirety and presented with high-quality zoomable images through an interface that supports browsing within individual manuscripts and across the collection.

Descriptions of the manuscripts have been encoded using the standard set forth in TEI Consortium, eds., TEI P5 Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange: Manuscript Description, at http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/MS.html as of 2012-09-22.

The TEI DTD used was obtained from the Digital Scriptorium of Columbia University at, https://www1.columbia.edu/sec/cu/libraries/bts/digital_scriptorium/technical/ds-xml/description_dtd/index.html on 2012-09-22. To accommodate specific project needs, the DTD was edited and extended with local tags in order to describe the content of miniatures, and the structure of canon tables, headpieces, and initials. The process of editing included equating the element Decoration with the seven recognized elements of the TEI Manuscript Description, not only to emphasize intellectual substance, but also to augment visibility by providing links from the record through encoding to the digitized imagery of the Web display.

overview.p: 17 miniatures consist of a portrait of the Evangelist Mark, and depictions of events drawn primarily from the cycles of Christ's miracles and Passion.

minItem.minDesc: Evangelist, Mark: Portrait. Mark writes, seated in high-backed chair before writing table; buildings in background.
Christ: Miracle of healing Peter's wife's mother. Christ stands at right, holds arm of the mother of Peter's wife who is seated in bed; Peter and other disciples wait behind Christ.
Christ: Miracle of healing paralytic. Christ stands at left, right hand raised in blessing; paralytic man lies on pallet at center, lowered from roof of building by two men; crowd, left background.
Christ: Miracle of raising daughter of Jairus. Christ stands at right, touches arm of Jairus' daughter who lies in bed, foreground; her mother and father wait, left background.
Christ: Miracle of loaves. Christ stands at center, looks down at two boys, seated at right, with baskets of fish and bread; mountains, in background.
Christ: Miracle of healing blind man. A blind man stands at left, holds cane, eyes closed. Christ, at center, touches the blind man's eyes.
Christ: Transfiguration. Christ, at center, on mountain; the prophets Elijah at left, and Moses to the right.
Christ: Entry into Jerusalem. Christ seated on donkey, at center; disciples and crowd in background; boy lays robe in road; man stands at right, arm raised.
Christ: Last Supper. Christ seated at center, a sleeping disciple to his left; other disciples sit on either side; wine cups, a compote, and plates of bread on table; buildings, in background.
Christ: Before Pilate. Pilate seated at left on throne behind cloth-covered table; Christ waits at right, eyes downcast, hands bound with rope held by soldier.
Christ: Barabbas released. Pilate, left hand raised, stands between prisoners Barabbas and Christ; men gesture, at right.
Christ: Mocked. Christ, kneels at center, crown of thorns on head; gesturing soldiers stand on either side, and in left background.
Simon of Cyrene: Bearing cross. Soldier leads Christ whose hands are bound with rope; Simon of Cyrene follows at left, carries cross on shoulder.
Christ: Casting of Lots for garments. Soldiers, either kneeling or standing, cast lots on top of Christ's robe and tunic.
Joseph of Arimathea: Before Pilate. Gesturing Pilate stands at left in front of throne; Joseph of Arimathea, hands crossed on chest, waits at right.
Holy Women: At sepulchre. Three women stand at left, hands raised; angel seated at right on stone from Christ's tomb.
